summary:
I am interested in transdisciplinary collaborations that focus on building design (processes) and human and planetary health (in a holistic sense), particularly situated in public buildings such as healthcare, schools and universities.

Health Promotion Building Design; Building design that inspires (vulnerable) populations to take control over the built environment that positively influences their health and quality of life. It was already known that the design of hospitals is important for healthcare quality. Plus, the built environment is important for a society that focuses on health promotion. However, in my work I showed that it is not clear what health promotion means in the field of healthcare building design. My work also showed that it is unclear, for people who work with health promotion in healthcare, how the built environment can contribute to health promotion. This makes it difficult to understand for those involved in building design processes to incorporate health promotion perspectives. Or for those that work with HPH how to utilise the built environment in the HPH development. This can lead to buildings that hinder health promotion approaches in the future while we need all disciplines to be involved to create healthier, equitable communities. 
 
I have studied different ideas about the design of health-promoting hospitals; health promotion and care architecture as presented in the literature and with people involved in building design projects. And  I studied what the built environment means for health promotion among the network that supports hospitals to become health promoters and in hospital organizations for health promotion. The studies have been done using literature studies, interviews, surveys and document analyses.

In my PostDoc, I focused on studying examples of what I would call precedents for future healthcare building design; those that pay attention to aspects of health promotion. Additionally, I am involved in developing methods that support the (re)design of hospital wards with special attention to healthy behaviours and equity. 
 
This research is important as many healthcare buildings need to be renovated or rebuilt, often with public funds. The results can support people who work with health promotion to incorporate the built environment in their ideas. The results hopefully result in improved healthcare buildings that play a role in the development of healthier communities.

Please contact me for more information.
If you want to connect; please add a note with your connection request.

Sustainability is already firmly embedded in architectural and urban conservation work, for example through adaptive re-use, retrofitting, and urban preservation. In this studio such questions are further developed through design exercises, design research, lectures and reading seminars, to engage with various aspects of environmental care, including rewilding, interspecies encounters, visionary environmental imaginations, and care for precarious environments and structures. Inspiration came from, for example, sustainable transformation practices, architectural theory and history, the environmental humanities, and landscape studies/design.
https://projects.arch.chalmers.se/ark626-fall21/
